awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Categorical Representation Theory of Hecke Algebras
awd_abstract_narration:
Representation theory is, roughly speaking, the study of groups of symmetries. For example, a mirror on a wall can help to visualize a reflection of 3-dimensional space, a symmetry which sends each point in our world to the corresponding point on the other side of the mirror. Coxeter groups are special kinds of groups of symmetries that consist of sequences of reflections through mirrors placed at precise angles to one another. The so-called "crystallographic" Coxeter groups occur frequently in physics and mathematics because they preserve lattice points, for example the locations of atoms in a crystal. Crystallographic Coxeter groups also arise when analyzing important geometric spaces; this imbues them with a great deal of interesting structure. Mysteriously, Coxeter groups which are not crystallographic still possess this beautiful structure, despite having no geometric explanation. For example, each Coxeter group has an associated Hecke algebra, and by multiplying elements in this algebra one can produce numbers called structure coefficients. For crystallographic Coxeter groups, these coefficients are always non-negative because they are counting something. However, the non-negativity result holds in general. An underlying goal of this project is to find combinatorial and algebraic descriptions of the structures apparent in Coxeter groups, to help explain these mysterious phenomena. The main objects of study are categorical representations of Hecke algebras, where usual reflections are replaced by "reflection functors" that act as symmetries not on some n-dimensional space, but on spaces attached to representations of other important algebras in mathematics.

In this research project the categorical representation theory of Hecke algebras will be investigated along three lines of attack. The first approach is to lift the notion of diagonalization from linear algebra to categorical representation theory. For example, the full twist in the braid group, and its image in the Hecke algebra, is diagonalizable in any finite dimensional representation. In joint work with Hogancamp, I aim to prove that the categorified full twist is "categorically  diagonalizable." This allows one to lift much of the structure  theory of Hecke algebra representations to the categorical level.  In the second approach, together with Williamson and Juteau, I will study certain categorical representations of affine Weyl groups which are significant for modular representation theory, and their quantum deformations. The goal is to compute local intersection forms, which will explain how the category degenerates in finite characteristic. This computation will give character formulas for modular representations of algebraic groups which were previously unknown. In the third approach, together with Young, I will find an algebraic description of the quantum deformation mentioned above, when the quantum parameter is a root of unity. This is related to the categorification of complex reflection groups, which is an open problem.

por.por_cntn:
This grant covered two main initiatives: research of the PI into a mathematical field known as categorifical representation theory, and a series of weeklong summer schools for graduate students in mathematics called WARTHOG (Workshop on Algebra and Representation Theory, held on Oregonian Grounds).

Mathematics is a deep and varied discipline, and graduate students spend many years trying to catch up with modern research even in one subfield. Summer schools are a common offering to help students bootstrap themselves to the modern day. WARTHOG, which has been running since 2010, has always had a unique approach amongst summer schools, which typically invite a slate of speakers to give several minicourses. Instead, we focus on one speaker and one topic, start at a "basic" level (where graduate coursework ends), and aim to get very deep into a new and exciting result. Along the way, graduate students learn techniques which are broadly applicable. Under this grant we have experimented with a new model for our workshops, adopting a schedule which alternates between one hour of lecture, and one hour spent doing one focused exercise. Our new approach has been immensely popular, spawning copycat workshops, and is discussed further in our article on conference organization written for the Notices of the American Mathematical Society. About 30-50 students have participated in WARTHOG each of the five years it was supported by this grant.

To describe the PIs research, we begin with the concept of linear algebra. Imagine several things one might do to a ball: rotate it around some axis, inflate it to twice its original size, squash it into a football-esque ellipsoid, etcetera. All of these are linear transformations because they behave well with respect to rescaling. I didn't tell you how big the ball was originally, and it doesn't matter.  Mathematics often has multiple ways to approach an idea: abstractly, and explicitly. Linear transformations can be thought of as abstract operations, or encoded in explicit matrices of numbers.

A collection of reversible transformations can be packaged into the mathematical concept of a group. For example, the collection of all transformations which preserve the shape and size of the ball form a group. This group can operate not just on the ball, but on a variety of objects in many possible dimensions.  Linear transformations and groups appear naturally as symmetries in far-ranging fields from chemistry and physics to computer graphics, and their study dates back to the 19th century.

Representation theory is the study of how a given group can operate in all dimensions. Representations are often built from smaller pieces which are stuck together in potentially complicated ways, like legos. To use a metaphor from chemistry, one wishes to classify the basic building blocks (the atoms, classified in the periodic table), compute how big they are (their mysterious atomic weights), and understand how they can be stuck together (into molecules). One can often forget the rich structure of representations or molecules and just remember numerical data, like in stoichiometry, where symbols like 2H_2 + O_2 = 2 H_2 O encode a potentially sophisticated reaction. In mathematics, we call this numerical data the "decategorification" of the "category" of representations.

A revolution occurred in the 1980s when it was realized that many of the most studied objects in representation theory were merely the decategorifications of a richer structure, a "categorification." The chemical metaphor breaks down as there is no "meta-chemistry!" A better metaphor comes from Plato's cave, where one realizes that one was only experiencing the shadow of something else. These categorifications were first constructed using high tech aspects of a field called algebraic geometry. Work of the PI and others in the last 15 years has helped to simplify and make explicit the construction of categorifications, and make them accessible to computers and graduate students alike. It is almost like taking an abstract linear transformation, and describing it simply using a matrix.

Supported partially by this grant, the PI and coauthors wrote the first graduate textbook on categorical representation theory, An Introduction to Soergel Bimodules. It is currently in use by many seminars worldwide, and has made a major impact on pedagogy in the field.

The research supported by this grant focuses on a number of key questions in categorical representation theory. These include: relating decomposition numbers (i.e. stoichiometry) in different settings by proving equivalence of categorifications; lifting the concept of diagonalization from linear algebra to the categorical level; making new categories explicit, and providing tools to help others do the same; uncovering new structures (like derivations) which appear surprisingly in categorifications; constructing categorifications for groups like G(m,m,n) where no geometric tools currently exist. It resulted in 13 research articles (half published, half still under review) and a number of additional works nearing completion.
